summary: studies have shown that nasally administered immunobiotics had the potential to improve the outcome of influenza virus infection. but the capacity of immunobiotics to improve protection against respiratory syncytial virus infection was not investigated before. aims of this study were to evaluate whether viability of Lr05 or Lr06 is indispensable to modulate respiratory immunity. acute lower respiratory tract infections are a persistent public health problem. there have been no significant changes in mortality in the last decades. respiratory infections are still among the primary causes of death worldwide. some studies have centered on whether immunoregulatory probiotic LAB (immunobiotics) might sufficiently stimulate the common mucosal immune system to provide protection in other mucosal sites distant from the gut. LAB treatments were related to an up-regulation of both respiratory innate and adaptive immune responses. lactobacillus rhamnosus CRL1505 (Lr05) and L. rhamnosus CRL1506 (Lr06) in this mice model, we found that orally administered Lr05 beneficially regulate the balance between pro-inflammatory mediators and IL-10 in lung of poly(I:C)-challenged mice. our results suggested that Lr05 is a potent inducer of antiviral cytokines and may be useful as a prophy microorganisms Lactobacillus rhamnosus CRL1505 (Lr05) and CRL1506 (Lr06) were obtained from the CERELA culture collection (Chacabuco 145, San Miguel de Tucumán, Argentina) both strains were selected because their previously reported immunomodulatory capacities [6,12] mice received 108 cells/mouse/day in 50 l of PBS. mice received three doses of poly(I:C) or PBS with 24 hs rest period.
